author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Dancing in the Dust’ Review: Marriage, Money and Morals
description: The first feature from Asghar Farhadi (“A Separation”) arrives in a remastered version on streaming services.
content: The debut feature from the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi, “Dancing in the Dust” never received a proper release in the United States. Now, 20 years after it was first shown, it is surfacing in a remastered version on streaming platforms. Two of Farhadi’s subsequent features (“A Separation” and “The Salesman”) won the Oscar for what was then called the best foreign language film, and he has become a reliable, methodical specialist in a certain brand of domestic drama. In Farhadi films, right and wrong are never clear-cut, and the suspense is intertwined with mounting moral complexities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Trump Autoworkers Speech Fact Check: What of Electric Vehicles?
description: The former president campaigned in Michigan during a strike by autoworkers but resorted to misleading claims to make the case for his candidacy.
content: As seven Republican presidential contenders debated on Wednesday night in California, former President Donald J. Trump, the front-runner for the nomination, spoke at an auto parts plant in Michigan, where he assailed President Biden’s policies embracing electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: TikTok Becomes a Flashpoint in the Second Republican Debate
description: Candidates clashed over whether the app was useful for reaching younger voters or dangerous because of its ties to China.
content: TikTok, the booming social media app, became a football in the Republican debate Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Republican Group Running Anti-Trump Ads Finds Little Is Working
description: With over 40 ads and $6 million spent, a group tied to the Club for Growth is no closer to an answer, a memo to donors says. Some ads even gave Donald Trump a boost.
content: A well-funded group of anti-Trump conservatives has sent its donors a remarkably candid memo that reveals how resilient former President Donald J. Trump has been against millions of dollars of negative ads the group deployed against him in two early-voting states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How Libraries Are Fighting Book Banning
description: Banned Books Week begins on Sunday, and the city’s library systems are mobilizing to support the freedom to read.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll see what libraries in New York City are doing to fight book banning. We’ll also see what Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, who has sent buses of migrants to New York, said during a visit to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sampson Starkweather and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: What if We Call This Tenderness
description: A poem that overlays love onto a previously loveless surface of the world.
content: Sampson Starkweather’s “What if We Call This Tenderness” is a poem that overlays love onto a previously loveless surface of the world. The ardent and persistent calls of a collection agency are notoriously unlikely to be resolved by poetry, but through this poem’s comparisons, their meaning is transformed. The poem becomes a charmed terrain where the “tender” that is money bows to a greater concept, tenderness. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: What to Know About the 2023 Nobel Prizes
description: The Nobel Prizes will be announced beginning Monday.
content: Nobel Prize season is upon us once again. Every October, committees in Sweden and Norway name laureates in a variety of prizes in the sciences, literature and economics, as well as peace work. In total, six prizes will be awarded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: New Trouble for China Evergrande
description: Plus the Japanese Formula 1 driver who became a cult star.
content: Two former executives at China Evergrande, the world’s most debt-saddled real estate developer, have been detained and the company’s billionaire chairman is under police surveillance, fueling fears of a deepening real estate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: How Dumbledore Became Michael Gambon’s Most Recognizable Role
description: The great British stage actor was not initially cast as the wizarding headmaster in the “Harry Potter” films, but he made the role his own.
content: In the latter part of Michael Gambon’s long and storied acting career, some of the most animated analyses of his performances could be found not in theater or film reviews, but in forums for the “Harry Potter” fandom, where dedicated Hogwarts obsessives would dissect his every onscreen utterance as the wizard Albus Dumbledore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Trump Could Lose Trump Tower (and Other Properties) in Fraud Case
description: If a judge’s ruling stands, Donald Trump could lose control over some of his flagship New York real estate.
content: A New York judge put a spotlight on former President Donald J. Trump’s business empire this week, determining in a ruling that he had inflated the value of his properties by considerable sums to gain favorable terms on loans and insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Celebrity Relationships
description: How much do you care about the love lives of the famous?
content: Have Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift taken over your social media feed this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Christine Hauser
title: Suspect in Killing of Baltimore Tech C.E.O. Pava LaPere Is Arrested
description: The murder of Ms. LaPere, who founded EcoMap Technologies, shocked Baltimore’s business community.
content: The suspect in the death of a young tech entrepreneur in Baltimore was arrested late Wednesday, ending a dayslong manhunt in which he eluded the authorities as they tracked his cellphone and spending activity, the Baltimore Police Department said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In Michigan, Biden and Trump Offer a Preview of 2024
description: The candidates’ dueling styles were on clear display as the two men tried to woo voters affected by the United Automobile Workers strike.
content: It’s going to be a long road to next November. And the first steps started this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Beloved Tree in England Is Felled in ‘Act of Vandalism’
description: Locals and tourists mourned the loss of one of Britain’s most photographed trees, which stood for hundreds of years in a dip in Hadrian’s Wall. The police said they had a suspect in custody.
content: A 16-year-old boy was arrested Thursday on suspicion of criminal damage after one of Britain’s most famous trees, a sycamore that stood in a dip in Hadrian’s Wall, was cut down overnight in what the authorities described as “an act of vandalism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: U.K. Regulator Investigates News Channel After Sexist Rant
description: Ofcom said it would investigate a commentator’s remarks on GB News, a right-leaning network that pitches itself as an alternative to mainstream British broadcasters.
content: Ofcom, Britain’s broadcasting regulator, opened a formal investigation on Thursday into a television news pundit’s tirade against a female journalist after receiving more than 7,000 complaints about his comments on GB News, a right-leaning network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Tiffany May
title: Chinese Activist Camps Out at Airport in Taiwan in Bid for Asylum
description: Chen Siming fled China and awaits refugee assistance in Taiwan, which is wary of raising tensions with Beijing by being seen as a haven for China critics.
content: Chen Siming, an activist who fled China, has been camped out at an airport in Taiwan for nearly a week, hoping to gain asylum in the West. He is willing to wait for much longer, as long as he is not forced to board a plane back to China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Creator’ Review: Or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love A.I.
description: In this hectic, futuristic action film, John David Washington hunts down a threatening artificial intelligence with the baby face of a child.
content: It’s been a tough year for artificial intelligence. First, industry leaders warn that A.I. poses an extinction-level threat to humanity. Then, screenwriters and actors warn roughly the same thing about artists losing their livelihoods (and art losing its soul). And let’s not forget predictions of vast unemployment and upheaval. What’s a superintelligent, terrifyingly autonomous technology got to do to get back on people’s good sides?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Lara Jakes
title: Western Leaders Urge Arms Manufacturing in Ukraine
description: NATO is pitching weapons making as economic development for war-torn Ukraine, and it could be lucrative for Western arms makers.
content: The chief of NATO and the defense ministers of Britain and France have paid surprise visits to Kyiv, announced on Thursday, in a show of continued solidarity, even as they emphasize the goal of pumping up weapons production within Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Quebec Lures $5 Billion Battery Factory for Electric Cars
description: The Canadian government matched financial incentives available in the U.S. to attract the investment from Northvolt, a Swedish company.
content: Northvolt, a Swedish maker of batteries for electric cars, said on Thursday that it would build a factory near Montreal after the Canadian government matched financial incentives that would have been available from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Said He Would Stop Drilling. Then Reality Hit.
description: The tug of war over one drilling lease in the Gulf of Mexico involving the president, Congress and the courts illustrates the limits of executive power.
content: Tens of thousands of climate protesters who filled Midtown Manhattan last week directed their anger at President Biden, who has done more to combat climate change than any of his predecessors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: Real Estate Broker Gets House Arrest in Homeless-Shelter Bribery Scheme
description: The broker, Sheina Levin, was a former business partner of Victor Rivera, whose dealings were the subject of a New York Times investigation.
content: A New York real estate broker was sentenced to nine months of house arrest this week for paying a former shelter operator hundreds of thousands of dollars in a yearslong bribery scheme to profit from city funding meant for homeless people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colette Coleman
title: Near the Catskills, a Rustic Estate Recast as an Artists’ Retreat
description: The British artists Gary Hume and Georgie Hopton are selling their 40-acre property in Accord, N.Y., dotted with antique outbuildings and an ultramodern studio, for $4.25 million.
content: After splitting their time between London and the foothills of the Catskill Mountains for over 20 years, the celebrated British artists Gary Hume and Georgie Hopton are saying goodbye to their expansive estate in Accord, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: A Young Designer Nabs a Viral Moment With Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift
description: As the founder of KidSuper, Colm Dillane has been floated as Virgil Abloh’s successor. But his most recent success? Being in proximity to pop stardom.
content: By now, you’ve very possibly heard the news, whether you wanted to or not: On Sunday, the 12-time Grammy Award-winning pop star Taylor Swift stoked recent dating rumors when she showed up at the Kansas City Chiefs game against the Chicago Bears to watch Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce lead the team to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Government Shutdown Looms
description: The situation serves as a reminder that partisan polarization in Washington is not symmetrical.
content: Two basic facts are central to understanding why the federal government may shut down on Sunday morning:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Texas Man Pleads Guilty in Human-Smuggling Attempt That Left 53 Dead
description: Christian Martinez is facing life in prison in connection to transporting migrants in a sweltering tractor-trailer that was left near San Antonio in June 2022.
content: A Texas man pleaded guilty to federal charges on Wednesday for his role in a human-smuggling attempt in which 53 people died last year, amid a growing border crisis, after they were picked up in a border town and were left in a sweltering tractor-trailer near San Antonio, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Sterlin Harjo on Ending ‘Reservation Dogs’ in That Good Way
description: The co-creator and showrunner talked about why three seasons was just right, and why the show is likely to be the most important thing he ever makes.
content: “All this, this is how the community works,” Hokti (Lily Gladstone) tells her grieving niece, Willie Jack (Paulina Alexis), in the series finale of FX’s “Reservation Dogs.” Sitting inside a prison visiting room and pointing to a circle made of candy bars, Cheez-Its and Flaming Flamers — ad hoc symbols of their loved ones, courtesy of a vending machine — Hokti continues: “It is sprawling. It spreads. What do you think they came for when they tried to get rid of us? Our community. You break that, and you break the individual.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea May Have Seen Little Benefit in Keeping U.S. Soldier
description: Why did the North expel Pvt. Travis T. King, rather than use him for its own purposes? Analysts say he was probably considered more of a burden than an asset.
content: When Pvt. ​Travis T. King fled to North Korea in July, he looked like a potential propaganda bonanza for Kim Jong-un’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Santul Nerkar
title: Drivers and Dealers Could Soon Feel Impact of U.A.W. Strikes
description: Lengthy and expanding walkouts by the United Automobile Workers union against Ford, General Motors and Stellantis could strain a fragile supply chain.
content: More than a week into its targeted strike at the three established U.S. car companies, the United Automobile Workers union has poked holes in a supply chain that has still not fully recovered from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: $10 and Under: In search of truly inexpensive dining
description: No, we didn’t forget to add another zero. Here are some precious places that serve a satisfying meal for a pittance.
content: In 1992, my colleague Eric Asimov invented a new column for the Times that sought out “restaurants where people can eat lavishly for $25 and under.” By the time it was retired, about a decade ago, dining out in New York had become expensive, even at the cheap end, and the column’s writers were regularly blowing past the $25 limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Romance Novels Brimming With Bookish Sorts
description: What better time than fall to look at academic romances?
content: It’s fall, the season of back-to-school, of new notebooks and fresh, unspoiled planners. So what more appropriate time to look at academic romances with scholarly leads?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: How West Africa Can Reap More Profit From the Global Chocolate Market
description: Resource-rich countries like Ghana are often cut out of lucrative parts of the business like manufacturing. The “fairchain movement” wants to change that.
content: The first leg of the 35-mile journey from Ghana’s capital city, Accra, to the Fairafric chocolate factory in Amanase on the N6 highway is a quick ride. But after about 30 minutes, the smoothly paved road devolves into a dirt expanse without lanes. Lumbering trucks, packed commuter minivans, cars and motorcycles crawl along craggy, rutted stretches bordered by concrete dividers, muddy patches and heaps of rock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Reptile’ Review: Unusual Suspects
description: Benicio Del Toro plays a detective investigating a suburban homicide in this overstuffed thriller.
content: The tortuous crime thriller “Reptile,” streaming on Netflix, at times feels like the unwise attempt to cram an entire season of a cops-and-perps show into just over two hours. The movie, peopled with a near-bottomless supply of unsavory rogues, tracks the aftermath of a grisly murder by trailing the policemen on the case. Domenick Lombardozzi (of “The Wire”) is even featured among the crew — although his presence is merely another reminder of the sharper stories this movie aspires to replicate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Key Takeaways From the G.O.P. Debate, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Sharon Otterman
title: ‘Ghost’ Guns Found at East Harlem Day Care Site, Officials Say
description: It was the second discovery this month of a lethal hazard at a home-based day care program in New York City.
content: An East Harlem apartment functioning as a state-licensed day care site was being used by the son of the site’s operator to produce 3-D-printed “ghost” guns and parts for them, officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Ukrainian successes in the Black Sea.
content: Ukraine is increasingly managing to gain a degree of control over part of the disputed waters of the Black Sea, aided by an intensifying military campaign and Ukraine’s growing ability to hit Russian warships, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: California Man Pleads Guilty to Setting Up Hundreds of Sham Marriages
description: The man, Marcialito Biol Benitez, 49, pleaded guilty in federal court in Boston in connection with a scheme to obtain green cards for hundreds of undocumented migrants.
content: A California man pleaded guilty this week to federal charges that he ran a fraudulent agency that arranged hundreds of sham marriages for clients trying to obtain green cards, according to the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Court Ruling Keeps Intact Minors’ Care for Transition
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 28, 2023.
content: “What we are practicing here is not voodoo. I think our justice system will see that there’s enough science to support this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: In Menendez Case, Prosecutors Confront Tighter Definition of Corruption
description: The Supreme Court has said wrongdoing must be clear cut. Some observers say the accusations in the senator’s case pass the test.
content: After the U.S. attorney in Manhattan announced corruption charges last Friday against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the veteran Democratic lawmaker lashed back, calling the claims false and saying prosecutors had “misrepresented the normal work of congressional office.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Kingsbury
title: Trump’s Promise of Lawlessness
description: The ex-president is running on a platform of lawlessness.
content: Though it was lost in the four-year cyclone that was the presidency of Donald Trump, one of his most immoral acts was to pardon soldiers who were accused of committing war crimes by killing unarmed civilians or prisoners. Military leaders, including his own defense secretary and the secretary of the Army objected, saying it would undermine good order and discipline. Lawlessness can easily beget lawlessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Wait, Is That a Live Butterfly in Your Skirt?
description: Nothing is what you think it is any more. Two great collections from Dries Van Noten and Undercover prove that’s OK.
content: The sense that things are not as they seem, that all the recognizable signposts suddenly look different and the world as you know it has gone topsy-turvy, is currently an everyday lament. You can have an existential crisis about it, or you can use it as a fuel for creativity. Surrealism followed the First World War; abstract expressionism, the Second. Often the worst of times produces the most interesting art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Nagorno-Karabakh Government Says It Will Disband
description: The announcement, formally ending more than 30 years of separatist rule, came after Azerbaijan regained control of the breakaway enclave in a swift attack a week ago.
content: The breakaway government of Nagorno-Karabakh said on Thursday that it would cease to exist, formally ending more than 30 years of separatist rule, a week after a swift attack by Azerbaijan returned the mountainous enclave to Azerbaijani rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: What Does It Take to Be a Vogue Model?
description: The fashion industry’s bible embarked on a public model search. There were 67,000 applications. What exactly were they looking for?
content: It is a curious moment in modeling.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: A poet, a pianist, a would-be painter: Our recommended books this week include several novels that feature artistic heroes (or antiheroes), along with a nonfiction study of classical music after the Holocaust that considers the at-times tenuous links between art and life. We also recommend a history of the pocket calculator, a tribute to life on the rugged Irish island Skellig Michael, and new novels from Hilary Leichter, Karl Ove Knausgaard and Emily Habeck. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Says He Would Sign a 15-Week Abortion Ban as President
description: The little-noticed remark came during a chaotic moment in the second G.O.P. debate. Mr. DeSantis signed a six-week abortion ban in Florida, but had not clearly committed to federal restrictions.
content: In the chaos of Wednesday night’s noisy Republican presidential debate, Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina interrupted Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to pose a question on abortion that Mr. DeSantis had dodged directly answering for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What’s Driving the September Stock Swoon
description: The S&P 500 is trading at a three-month low as surging oil prices, rising bond yields and concerns about economic growth send investors to the exits.
content: Stocks are heading for their worst month of the year as a triple whammy of soaring bond yields, rising oil prices and slowing growth trigger a widespread sell-off, even in once-loved mega-cap tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reed and Patricia Mazzei
title: After Hurricane Ian, Who Will Get to Call This Beach Town Home?
description: Unlike its wealthier neighbors, Fort Myers Beach had an unpolished charm and a more economically diverse population before the devastating storm.
content: Melissa Hill has gotten used to the transformed view outside the restaurant where she tends bar in Fort Myers Beach: the concrete slabs where bustling businesses once stood, the bald fishing pier pilings, the elevator shaft that is the only, eerie remnant of a two-story shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: This Is What Is Worrying Me About the War in Ukraine
description: Ukraine is still David. Russia is still Goliath.
content: One of the most important things to do when writing and thinking about the course of a war is the hardest for a journalist — it’s to wait. Don’t say anything and watch events unfold. When analyzing or covering a conflict, there are some things that are immediately apparent — like the failure of a Russian missile attack over Kyiv, or Ukraine’s urgent military need for better fighter aircraft — but other seemingly simple questions are surprisingly difficult to answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Nashawn Breedlove, Rapper Who Dueled Eminem in ‘8 Mile,’ Dies at 46
description: He drew praise for his scene in the film, in which he belittled Eminem’s character with sarcastic lyrics, a gruff voice and an imposing presence.
content: Nashawn Breedlove, the actor who received acclaim for his scene in the rap-to-riches film “8 Mile,” in which he delivers a tenacious freestyle in a battle against the character portrayed by the rapper Eminem, commanding the gloomy stage with his blustery lyrics and imposing presence, died on Sunday at his home in Newark, N.J. He was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: His Music Spanned Classical and Disco. Now a ‘Lost’ Work Sounds Again.
description: Arthur Russell, a victim of AIDS, composed fluidly in many genres. His “City Park” has been reconstructed for a new generation.
content: Arthur Russell — former Midwesterner, avant-gardist in the making — moved to New York from San Francisco in the early 1970s to study at the Manhattan School of Music, where his teachers included the composer Charles Wuorinen. It wasn’t a happy relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Watchdog Urges Extending Surveillance Law With New Limits
description: In a report about an expiring law that has generated intense debate in Congress, a government panel split over requiring court permission to view Americans’ communications.
content: An independent watchdog agency that investigates the nation’s security programs unanimously urged Congress in a report made public on Thursday to reauthorize an expiring and much-debated law that allows warrantless surveillance of targeted foreigners even when they are communicating with or about Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: A Somali Pantry Pasta Rich With Warming Spices
description: “This is one of the best pastas I’ve made from NYT Cooking.”
content: At this point, we’re guessing you have a regular rotation of pantry pastas that you turn to when you’re tired, stressed and need dinner now. Maybe you have already mastered midnight pasta, and pull out sardine puttanesca when you need something a bit more substantial. If so, Ifrah F. Ahmed’s new recipe for baasto iyo suugo tuuna — pasta with spiced tuna sauce, a staple in many Somali households — should be next on your list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: The Potty-Mouthed, Baby-Faced Japanese Racer Who Became a Cult Star
description: The impish persona and insouciant attitude of the Formula 1 driver Yuki Tsunoda have overturned stereotypes. The next step? Showing he can keep up with rivals.
content: The pressure was on Yuki Tsunoda. Within days, he would compete in a Formula 1 race in his home country, Japan. Bad luck had forced him out of two previous races minutes before the start, and speculation was rife that he might be demoted after some disappointing performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Naming Children After Pets
description: Should a baby carry on the legacy of a beloved dog?
content: Alicia writes: My wife and I were discussing names for our daughter, and I suggested Sadie — the name of my childhood dog. My wife vetoed it. She thinks you shouldn’t name children after pets. I disagree. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Some Problems With Contemporary Ballet
description: Philadelphia’s BalletX, a company dedicated to presenting new works, falters with a triple bill at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan.
content: As a genre, contemporary ballet can feel nebulous and far-reaching — for better or worse, anything goes. In the case of BalletX, a Philadelphia company formed by Christine Cox and Matthew Neenan in 2005, the aim is to produce new works expanding the possibilities of ballet. It’s a noble cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Top Biden Aides Questioned in Inquiry Into Handling of Documents
description: The special counsel investigating how classified material ended up at President Biden’s think tank and home after his vice presidency has interviewed senior White House and cabinet officials.
content: Robert K. Hur, the special counsel investigating President Biden’s handling of classified documents while serving as vice president, has interviewed many of Mr. Biden’s closest aides and advisers in a quiet inquiry that over the last nine months has reached into the upper levels of the White House and the cabinet, people familiar with the case said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 28, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about high electricity prices in Texas misstated the given name of an analyst who follows energy markets for Public Citizen. He is Tyson Slocum, not Tyron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: M. S. Swaminathan, Scientist Who Helped Conquer Famine in India, Dies at 98
description: Called the father of India’s Green Revolution, he served on agencies and boards around the world and developed a system of ecologically safe food production.
content: M.S. Swaminathan, the eminent crop geneticist who fused plant breeding science with keen administrative skills to produce bountiful harvests that ended famine and steadily transformed India into one of the world’s top growers of wheat and rice, died on Thursday in Chennai, India. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Justice Dept. Accuses Trump Lawyers of Dragging Their Feet in Documents Case
description: Prosecutors said the former president’s defense team was trying to use an arcane law to derail the scheduled start of his trial on charges of mishandling classified material and obstructing justice.
content: Federal prosecutors on Thursday accused former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers of trying to employ an arcane law governing the use of classified material to “intentionally derail” the timing of his trial on charges of mishandling national security documents and obstructing efforts to retrieve them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: ‘Unpredictability in the System,’ and Other Travel Lessons From the Summer of ’23
description: Climate change upheavals brought on a season of extremes for travelers in the U.S., Europe and beyond. One thing is clear: Travel is changing.
content: Kia Karjalainen and her sister were vacationing in Greece when things took an unexpected turn. “We were in our hotel room, and I suddenly said to my sister, ‘It really, really smells of smoke. Is something burning?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Is Attacked Over China, Ukraine and TikTok
description: Even the typically mild-mannered former Vice President Mike Pence took swipes at Mr. Ramaswamy.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy was a standout last month in the first Republican presidential debate. In the second debate on Wednesday, he was a target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Delta to Adjust SkyMiles Program After Customer Outcry
description: Delta’s chief executive, Ed Bastian, said the airline would make “modifications” after announcing changes to its frequent flier program that angered many of its most loyal customers.
content: Delta Air Lines will make “modifications” to its SkyMiles frequent flier program after receiving negative feedback from customers to changes it announced this month, the company’s chief executive, Ed Bastian, said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: First Impeachment Hearing Yields No New Information on Biden
description: In a chaotic session, Republicans accused the president of crime and corruption, but even their witnesses said the case for impeachment hadn’t been made.
content: The first hearing in House Republicans’ impeachment inquiry into President Biden featured their star witnesses testifying that they lacked proof that he committed impeachable offenses, multiple procedural skirmishes the G.O.P. majority nearly lost and, at times, nearly a dozen empty Republican seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: New York Is Rebounding for the Rich. Nearly Everyone Else Is Struggling.
description: The huge income gap between rich and poor in Manhattan is the latest sign that the economic recovery from the pandemic has been lopsided in New York City.
content: As New York City inches closer to recovering all the jobs it lost during the pandemic, Manhattan — the city’s economic engine — marked a far less encouraging milestone. It now has the biggest income gap of any large county in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What to Do if Your Dog Has No Chill
description: How do you solve a problem like Commander? After the president’s dog bit (another) Secret Service officer, trainers weigh in on how to handle a dog’s aggression.
content: In 1907, The Washington Post detailed the misbehavior of a headstrong resident of the White House. “He is a great fighter and craves trouble,” the newspaper wrote of Theodore Roosevelt’s “prized bull terrier,” Pete, who had bitten the leg of a Navy clerk and chased the French ambassador up a tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Who Won the Debate? Rivals Struggle to Shine With Trump Offstage
description: Pundits thought Nikki Haley, Ron DeSantis and Tim Scott delivered sharp performances, though they did not damage the front-runner, Donald Trump.
content: The second Republican president debate on Wednesday night featured personal and policy clashes between the candidates, plenty of fire directed at “Bidenomics,” and the taunting of former President Donald J. Trump, the front-runner who once again declined to join his rivals onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Viewership Fell Sharply for Second G.O.P. Debate
description: Fewer than 10 million people watched the Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday, according to preliminary data from Nielsen.
content: Fewer than 10 million people watched the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, according to preliminary data from Nielsen, a sign that interest in the race is waning without the presence of former President Donald J. Trump, the front-runner for his party’s nomination, who has so far refused to participate in the debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: For Martha’s Vineyard Locals, Weddings Help Pay the Bills
description: The nearly 100-square-mile island is a popular destination for couples seeking a picturesque destination. But some residents who work these lavish nuptials face hardships beyond the aisle.
content: On a typical weekend in the spring, summer and early fall, Martha’s Vineyard transforms into a wedding haven, with tall white tents dotting green lawns and rolling farm fields that often overlook the scenic shoreline. Situated off the coast of southeastern Massachusetts, the Vineyard has become a popular destination for couples seeking a scenic seaside escape for their nuptials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘What Is War to a Grieving Child?’
description: How are Ukrainian children dealing with the horrors and trauma of war?
content: Note to Teachers: The film includes graphic language and footage. Please preview it to make sure it is appropriate for your students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Introducing The Times’s New San Francisco Bureau Chief
description: I’ve written a lot about the city’s many crises. But there’s so much more to this place that I’ve called home for 24 years.
content: Many San Franciscans know the feeling, that moment when it hits you: “I live here, and I’m lucky.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Nowhere’ Review: Sensationalism at Sea
description: This thriller from the Spanish director Albert Pintó follows a pregnant refugee forced to survive in a shipping container adrift in the ocean.
content: Disasters at sea have provided audiences with lurid thrills for hundreds of years, if not thousands. “Nowhere,” the latest addition to the seafaring survivalist tradition, won’t be remembered for long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: IBM Tries to Ease Customers’ Qualms About Using Generative A.I.
description: The company will assume the legal risk of businesses that use its A.I. systems and will publish the technology’s underlying data.
content: There is no shortage of excitement in corporate America for the new artificial intelligence that can produce everything from business reports to computer code with humanlike fluency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: ‘Carlos’ Review: Santana’s Soulful Legacy
description: In Rudy Valdez’s poignant but shortsighted documentary, the guitarist’s magic comes alive in performances and childhood recollections.
content: Since his breakthrough at the Fillmore in San Francisco and then a star-making performance at Woodstock in 1969, Carlos Santana’s fusion of improvisational Latin rock and blues has been regarded as transcendent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The ’24 Race: More Hats in the Ring?
description: We ask readers, “Who else would you like to see in the race besides all the announced candidates in both parties?”
content: It’s no exaggeration to say that a majority of voters are not eager for another contest between Joe Biden and Donald Trump. Who else would you like to see in the race besides all the announced candidates in both parties? Make your best argument for that choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: An Aristocrat’s Grandson, a Precious Desk and a Storage Unit in Queens
description: Christian Agostino von Hassell lost a trove of family heirlooms intertwined with European history when he encountered New York’s unforgiving laws governing storage lockers.
content: The 18th-century French writing desk that once belonged to Ulrich von Hassell, a German diplomat executed on the orders of Adolf Hitler, had sat for 12 years in a self-storage unit in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Studios and Striking Actors Will Resume Talks on Monday
description: The two sides announced the step a day after the leadership of the Hollywood writers’ union approved a tentative deal that ended its monthslong strike.
content: Hollywood is moving one step closer to getting back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Humans Got Too Close to the Sea Lions. Now They’re Closing the Beach.
description: The San Diego City Council unanimously voted to close a 150-yard stretch of coastline known as Point La Jolla after selfie-taking visitors got too close to the pinnipeds.
content: A popular San Diego beach has long been the domain of sea lions, which for years tolerated their human onlookers — some more respectful than others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Purlie Victorious’ Throws a Comic Funeral for Racism
description: Ossie Davis’s 1961 play is no period piece, as a blazing and hilarious revival starring Leslie Odom Jr. testifies.
content: Two years before he made his “I Have a Dream” speech at the March on Washington in 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. attended the 100th performance of “Purlie Victorious” at the Cort Theater on Broadway. He knew the playwright, Ossie Davis, and his wife, Ruby Dee, from their work in the civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Celebrity Memorabilia Becomes the Star of Auction Season
description: As the art market wobbles, estate sales are filling holes in the auction calendar.
content: Within the living room where she entertained heads of state and celebrities, the broadcast journalist Barbara Walters exhibited two pictures in gilded frames. One was a commissioned portrait of herself in a luxurious gown. The other was a painting of a stoic Egyptian woman in a black head scarf — created in 1891 by one of the most beloved painters in American history, John Singer Sargent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: In a Sartorial About-Face, Senate Reverts to Tradition on Its Dress Code
description: A week after the top Senate Democrat announced a more casual standard for dress in the chamber, a bipartisan pair won passage of a measure requiring that business attire be worn.
content: After a brief departure from tradition that was tailored for Senator John Fetterman, the Pennsylvania Democrat who pressed to vote and preside in shorts and a hoodie rather than a business suit, the Senate on Wednesday formalized a longstanding — but previously unofficial — requirement that members show up to the chamber in business attire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: In Cocoon, a Journey Between Mysterious Worlds Awaits
description: The much-anticipated video game designed by Jeppe Carlsen, the brain behind the puzzles in Limbo and Inside, seeks to deliver pleasurable moments of discovery.
content: Long before the emergence of a winged protagonist who transports powerful orbs across the mysterious landscape of Cocoon, the adventure video game was an abstract computer science exercise gestating in its creator’s head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: It’s the Best Time of the Year to Run. Try a 5K or 10K.
description: You don’t need to run 26.2 miles to enjoy marathon season. Here’s how to prepare for shorter distances.
content: There’s nothing better than fall running — the leaves, the crisp air. This is your reward for slogging through summer’s heat and humidity. Race directors know it, too, which is why there are so many fall races on the calendar. Whether it’s for a 5K or a half-marathon, now is a good time to register for a short or medium-length race and start preparing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Rina Forms, Far from Land, in the Atlantic Ocean
description: Forecasters weren’t certain of Rina’s projected path because of its proximity to Tropical Storm Phillipe.
content: Tropical Storm Rina formed over the central part of the tropical Atlantic Ocean on Thursday, becoming the 17th named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. Its life span and path depend on its interaction with Tropical Storm Philippe but it most likely will not affect land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: griot
description: This word has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word griot has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 2 in “For Her New Play, Tori Sampson Revisited Her ‘Black Power Household’” by Naveen Kumar:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: What’s the Story Behind Mu Shu Pork and Bird’s Nest Soup?
description: In “Chinese Menu,” Grace Lin takes readers and eaters on a food tour that dates back to 7000 B.C.
content: There are few leather-bound books more satisfying to pore over than the ones you find on a table at a Chinese restaurant. The words inside read like poetry — General Tso’s chicken, Buddha’s delight, sizzling rice soup — and conjure images that put Shakespearean sonnets to shame. The paperback edition (also known as a takeout menu) has the same Pavlovian effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: There’s a Crucial Question About Trump, Real Estate and Fraud
description: There’s no doubt he vastly exaggerated the value of his assets, but much of the real estate industry makes claims that are reliably unreliable.
content: The New York attorney general’s lawsuit against Donald Trump over his real estate business hinges on one question: Where does puffery end and fraud begin? To put it differently, how much can Mr. Trump overstate what he’s worth before he crosses the line into illegality?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Carl Hulse and Karoun Demirjian
title: Border Takes Center Stage as McCarthy Seeks to Shift Shutdown Blame
description: The Republican speaker is working to turn the shutdown fight into a border security battle. Some lawmakers in both parties say they are open to including immigration provisions in an eventual deal.
content: As Congress barrels toward a government shutdown instigated by his own hard-right members, Speaker Kevin McCarthy is toiling to turn a fight over federal spending into a battle over President Biden’s handling of the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: An Appeals Court Rejected Trump’s Effort to Delay His Fraud Trial
description: Also, a government shutdown is looking likely. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: Donald Trump’s civil fraud trial over accusations that he inflated the value of his properties by billions of dollars could begin as soon as Monday, after a New York appeals court rejected the former president’s attempt to delay it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Swiss Court Acquits Belarusian in Disappearance of Opposition Leaders
description: Lawyers for the relatives of the three victims who vanished in 1999 said they planned to appeal the decision.
content: A former member of a Belarusian security services unit on trial for the disappearance of three prominent opponents of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko in 1999 has been acquitted by a Swiss court after judges ruled his testimony was unreliable, according to a decision released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Barbie
description: We invited teenagers to weigh in on all things Barbie — the doll, the movie, the cultural phenomenon. Here’s what they had to say.
content: “Barbie,” the movie, was the blockbuster hit of the summer, earning over $1.4 billion worldwide, and demonstrating that the 64-year-old plastic doll still holds an important place in our collective psyche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Only Shot That Those Seven Republicans Have to Stop Trump
description: On Wednesday night, none of them took it.
content: Donald Trump won’t be defeated with sound bites. He won’t be bested with wordplay. Ron DeSantis carped repeatedly that Trump was “missing in action” at the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, while Chris Christie called Trump a coward and christened him “Donald Duck.” How very clever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jorja Smith Puts a Beat Behind Mixed Emotions on ‘Falling or Flying’
description: The English songwriter uses vocal nuance instead of volume and lets the rhythms stir things up on her second studio album.
content: There’s always a forlorn edge to Jorja Smith’s voice, even when things are going well. “A love like this is nothing I have known before,” she sings on “Make Sense,” a track from her new album, “Falling or Flying.” Even as she rejoices, “A home in you I’ve found,” the chords circle around a minor key and she sounds cautious, almost disbelieving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: National Parks, and Those Who Count on Them, Brace for Possible Shutdown
description: People, businesses and towns relying on park tourism worry the fourth shutdown in a decade could crush them if Congress can’t reach a deal to keep the government running.
content: It’s wedding season at Acadia National Park in Maine, and Tabitha Brown can barely keep up with the demand for her “luxury picnics” — champagne and charcuterie served seaside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Trump Will Not Seek to Move Georgia Racketeering Case to Federal Court
description: His decision comes after Mark Meadows, his former chief of staff, tried unsuccessfully to move his own case from state to federal court.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will not seek to move the criminal racketeering case against him in Atlanta to federal court, according to a legal filing from his lawyer on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Eliza Triantafillou
title: Gifts, Gadgets and Greece: Inside a Huawei Lobbying Campaign
description: Leaked internal messages detail efforts by the Chinese tech giant to court Greek officials and fight an American-led effort against its technology.
content: In November 2020, executives at Huawei, the Chinese telecom-equipment maker, exchanged messages about holding a meeting with a “friend” and an “adviser” in Greece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Government Shutdown May Hurt Home Sales in Flood-Prone Areas
description: Congress funds a flood insurance program that many home buyers in risky areas rely on. The money is about to run out, a real estate trade group warned.
content: A new entry may soon join hurricanes and atmospheric rivers on the list of large-scale problems roiling the housing and insurance industries in the United States: congressional gridlock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: The 12 Most Styles-ish Fashion Books Coming Out This Fall
description: Pharrell, Thom Browne and Linda Evangelista are all contributing to a starry season for fashion publishing.
content: It is fashion month, that season when a certain crowd jets between catwalks in New York, London, Milan and Paris. Once everyone is cozily back at home, what better coda than a book — or two — from the bounty of fashion titles adding a little coolness to the fall publishing schedule?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Newsom Is in the Spin Room to Pump Up Biden, and Maybe Himself
description: Gavin Newsom predictably declared Joe Biden the winner of the second G.O.P. debate. Another big winner? Gavin Newsom.
content: For much of Wednesday evening, Gavin Newsom, the Democratic governor of California, drew nearly as much attention at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and Museum in Simi Valley, Calif., as the Republican presidential candidates who were there for their second debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends checking out an old-school stand-up special, a British makeup competition series and a kooky Australian dramedy.
content: ‘Django Gold: Bag of Tricks’When to watch: Now, on YouTube.

title: How to Use Up That Tomato Paste
description: Tomato-lentil soup, vegetarian Bolognese and cheesy white bean-tomato bake are here to make the most of that open can.
content: A few months ago, on the hunt for topics for this fine newsletter, I polled the masses (read: asked people on Instagram) for the ingredients they struggled to use up. The deafening chorus of “tomato paste” replies could not be ignored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Emma Bubola
title: Three Killed in Shootings at a Home and a Medical School in Rotterdam
description: A 32-year-old student of the medical school was arrested as a suspect in the shootings, the police said, but a motive remained unclear.
content: A woman, her teenage daughter and a man were killed on Thursday after a gunman opened fire at a house and a prominent medical school in the Dutch port city of Rotterdam, an unusual outburst of gun violence in the city that the police chief called a “black day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 18 New Books Coming in October
description: Buzzy new novels from Jesmyn Ward, Tananarive Due and Daniel Clowes; biographies of Madonna and Sam Bankman-Fried; John Grisham’s sequel to “The Firm”; and much more.
content: Thrall first recounted the story of Abed Salama’s search for his 5-year-old son after a bus crash on the outskirts of Jerusalem in a 2021 piece for The New York Review of Books. Now he’s expanded it, weaving the wrenching human saga with a history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: The A.I. Wars Have Three Factions, and They All Crave Power
description: A covert war to determine the regulatory future of A.I. is being waged by deeply divided camps with divergent motivations.
content: There is no shortage of researchers and industry titans willing to warn us about the potential destructive power of artificial intelligence. Reading the headlines, one would hope that the rapid gains in A.I. technology have also brought forth a unifying realization of the risks — and the steps we need to take to mitigate them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: The Chicken That Might Put a Ring on It
description: Can a comforting dish called “Marry Me Chicken” really move a partner to propose? These home cooks say yes.
content: The quickest way to someone’s heart is through their stomach, or so the saying goes. But what if a piece of chicken, drenched in a sun-dried tomato cream sauce, was the best shortcut to the altar?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Effort to Delay Trial in Fraud Case
description: Former President Donald J. Trump had sued the judge presiding over his case, Arthur F. Engoron, aiming to pause a trial that will likely begin as soon as Monday.

content: This album, the Sphinx Virtuosi’s debut on the storied Deutsche Grammophon label, is most valuable as promotion for the ensemble’s parent, the Sphinx Organization, which is devoted to increasing racial diversity in classical music and turned 25 last year. Sphinx offers competitions, conferences, training programs, grants and audition support, alongside advocacy for young soloists and arts administrators, for more diverse rosters and repertory.

description: Brazil’s JBS produces 32 billion pounds of animal products a year.
content: The list of individual companies that have a meaningful impact on global greenhouse gas emissions is relatively short, and dominated by oil and gas producers. Think Exxon, Shell, Chevron and BP.

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Museum Worker Sold Paintings and Put Forgeries in Their Place
description: An in-house appraiser noticed something was awry when the canvas on his workbench did not match a catalog entry.
content: A worker at the Deutsches Museum in Munich stole paintings from the collection, replaced them with rough forgeries, then sold the originals at auction, according to the judgment of a court in the city this month. The thief used the proceeds to finance a luxurious lifestyle, the judge said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China Uses ‘Deceptive’ Methods to Sow Disinformation, U.S. Says
description: The accusations reflect worry in Washington that China’s information operations pose a growing security challenge to the United States.
content: The State Department accused China on Thursday of using “deceptive and coercive methods” to shape the global information environment, by acquiring stakes in foreign newspapers and television networks, using major social media platforms to promote its views and exerting pressure on international organizations and media outlets to silence critics of Beijing.

title: Pope Francis Has Put His Stamp on the Cardinals. Or Has He?
description: When Pope Francis formally elevates 21 cardinals on Saturday, he will have appointed a large majority of the men who will elect his successor.
content: When Pope Francis anoints 21 new princes of the Roman Catholic Church on Saturday, he will seem to have consolidated his grip on the powerful College of Cardinals — and on the direction of the church, possibly for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastien Lai
title: ‘Don’t Be Scared,’ My Father Said Before He Was Led Away in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong must release Jimmy Lai to prove that rule of law in the city is not dead.
content: I haven’t seen my father, Jimmy Lai, in three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: This Vegetarian Dinner Party Menu Lets the Host Relax
description: A smoky eggplant salad, a squash pie inspired by Moroccan b’stilla and saffron-poached pears can all be made ahead, with minimal fussing, David Tanis writes.
content: Most of the time, I take a very casual approach to having guests for dinner. I don’t mind doing a little cooking while people hang out in the kitchen; in fact, I enjoy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Lescaze
title: How Chelsea Became the Unlikely Center of the Art World
description: The art business took over a neighborhood on the Far West Side of Manhattan previously known as Gasoline Alley. Then the city turned the area into a ‘monument to real estate developers.’
content: THE NEW YORK art dealer Pat Hearn was two days away from signing a fresh lease on her gallery space in SoHo when the phone rang on a snowy Sunday night in the spring of 1994. Paul Morris, a fellow dealer who knew she was restless, suggested that they open galleries in Chelsea. “Why would I move to Chelsea?” Hearn recalled thinking. The formerly industrial neighborhood was a better place to get an oil change than to see an exhibition. SoHo was the undisputed heart of the downtown art world. But Hearn was intrigued, and she spent the next day with Morris visiting warehouses near the Hudson River. The installation artist Tom Burr, who showed with Hearn’s partner, Colin de Land, recalled her bursting into a restaurant sometime later and describing the new space she’d found: a former garage on West 22nd Street. Burr thought Hearn was crazy. “It just seemed so completely remote and inconceivable,” he said. “Going over to the Far West Side really did feel like you were traveling to the end of the earth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: The Messy G.O.P. Debate Didn’t Turn Off These Voters
description: Ron DeSantis won praise for his education policies and Nikki Haley got points for passion at a debate watch party in New Hampshire.
content: The voters gathered at a brewery in Goffstown, N.H., to watch the second Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night were excited about many of the options on the stage at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library. They were also looking forward to having fewer of them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Thanks to Taylor Swift, Ranch Dressing Is ‘Seemingly’ Everywhere
description: After a photo of the pop superstar at an N.F.L. game last weekend went viral, snack and condiment companies raced to capitalize.
content: Can’t get enough of the budding relationship between Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce? Neither can ranch dressing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Vulnerable Republicans Try to Head Off Blame for Shutdown
description: Some mainstream House Republicans representing districts won by President Biden have explored a bipartisan stopgap measure as right-wing lawmakers push Congress toward a shutdown.
content: Days before an all-but-certain government shutdown instigated by hard-right Republicans in Washington, Elizabeth Catalino arrived at a Hudson Valley high school looking for answers from her own G.O.P. congressman, Representative Mike Lawler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Enough About Gram Parsons’s Death. It’s Time to Celebrate His Music.
description: The country-rock pioneer died 50 years ago at age 26 with two influential solo albums to his name, leaving a legion of “what if”s behind.
content: More than almost any other musician, the country-rock pioneer Gram Parsons’s legacy is entwined with the story of his tragic death, 50 years ago this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Saturn’s Rings May Have Formed in a Surprisingly Recent Crash of 2 Moons
description: Researchers completed a complex simulation that supports the idea that the giant planet’s jewelry emerged hundreds of millions of years ago, not billions.
content: Try to imagine Saturn without its signature rings. Now picture two large icy moons shifting closer together little by little until — boom. Chaos. What was solid is now fluid. Diamantine shards scatter into the darkness. Many icy fragments tumble close to Saturn, remain there and dance around the gas giant in unison, ultimately forging the heavyweight body’s exquisite discs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Hazlehurst
title: A New Standard-Bearer for French-Girl Style
description: Jane Birkin made the look famous. Now Jeanne Damas is selling her version of it to the masses through her clothing brand, Rouje.
content: Sitting outside at Gemma, the restaurant at the Bowery Hotel in Lower Manhattan, Jeanne Damas offered a textbook example of what many might call French-girl style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Sikh Separatism Is a Nonissue in India, Except as a Political Boogeyman
description: India’s feud with Canada highlights how Prime Minister Narendra Modi has amplified a separatist threat that in reality is largely a diaspora illusion.
content: During his first trip to India as Canada’s prime minister in 2018, Justin Trudeau made a visit to the northern state of Punjab, where he got a photo op in full Punjabi dress at the Golden Temple, the holiest site of the Sikh religion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yinka Elujoba
title: For Barkley Hendricks, Finally a Seat at the Head of the Table
description: An underground virtuoso, always being discovered in bits and pieces, the portraitist solidifies his place in the canon with a solo show at the Frick — its first ever for a Black artist.
content: One day, in the late 1970s, while walking the streets of Pigalle in Paris, the American painter Barkley L. Hendricks noticed several well-dressed Black men and women. As Hendricks later explained, he was particularly struck by the fashion sense of two African men. He spent time photographing them in different postures and situations, as was his habit with models he painted, laying the foundation for work that would end up on his canvas. The resultant painting — “APB’s (Afro-Parisian-Brothers)” — is eternally modern even in our time, relentlessly cool, and luxuriously vibrant, qualities that radiate through his ongoing exhibition of portraits at the Frick, where he is the first artist of color to have a solo show in the museum’s 88 years of existence. It is a posthumous glory: Hendricks died in 2017, at age 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Flora and Son’ Review: Once, With More Feeling
description: The writer-director John Carney, whose feature “Once” made musical waves, returns with another charming songwriter tale.
content: “Flora and Son,” a satisfying demimusical from the Irish writer and director John Carney (“Once,” “Sing Street”), opens with an unexpected blast of techno. This kind of hard, sweaty beat propels our churlish heroine Flora (Eve Hewson), although by the end of the first sequence, it’s clear that the clubbing, and the booze, and the one-night stands have given her a perpetual hangover. Barely in her 30s, the self-destructive single mother is throwing away her future with an assist from her feckless ex, Ian (Jack Reynor, sputtering and hilarious), and their 14-year-old son, Max (Oren Kinlan), a thief and would-be rapper. It’s a testament to Hewson’s extraordinary charisma that her character can openly wish Max would get kidnapped and we root for her anyway. But since she’s saddled with the boy, Flora foists a junked guitar on him as a birthday present. “It’s a piano,” she jokes. The lad is unimpressed.

In theory, nasal sprays could be one way to do that, offering an extra layer of defense precisely where the virus enters the body. Ideally, you could use a spray to reduce your risk of infection in the days before, during and after events where you have a higher likelihood of being exposed to Covid.

Shooting in a narrow aspect ratio, the director, Aristotle Torres, who expanded this debut feature from a short, seems as interested in capturing snapshots of a cinematically neglected pocket of New York — its graffiti murals, its alleyways, its restaurants tucked under elevated train tracks — as he is in the plot. She has really only heard about the big names, though, and it seems possible that many smaller, less competitive colleges might be a better fit. I recently signed with a college-consultant company, at a cost of a few thousand dollars, to help us navigate the application process. My daughter is uncomfortable with this and feels that it gives her an unfair advantage other kids don’t have; she says she wants to apply on her own merit. But many kids are using these services, perhaps even more exclusive ones, and some people have an advantage because of personal connections. Also, from what I hear, the college-application process can be overwhelming.

title: A Tasting Room for Black Currant Liquor in Upstate New York
description: Plus: a new seasonal restaurant in Brooklyn, a Marisol retrospective — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: The Danish chef Mads Refslund first began working on Ilis, his new restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 2016. After years of high-profile jobs at places like Manhattan’s Acme and Shou Sugi Ban House in the Hamptons, Refslund, a co-founder of Noma, wanted a permanent space where he could create an immersive culinary experience. The open kitchen, and its live fire grill, is at the center of the 4,800-square foot room on Green Street. The space has 17-foot ceilings with wooden beams and exposed brick walls; custom rosewood tables and leather banquettes frame the perimeter (though a few counter seats provide the best vantage of a meal coming together). “This is about transparency,” Refslund says. The name Ilis is a portmanteau of sorts, with ild meaning “fire” in Danish and is meaning “ice.” It’s a nod to the dichotomous spirit of the restaurant — serious cooking with laid-back dinner party vibes. The menu allows guests to choose from a selection of primary ingredients, say New England scallops or Pennsylvania wild duck, and, in some cases, style of preparation (raw or grilled, for example). The seasonal cuisine is informed by Refslund’s Scandinavian upbringing, as well as his travels to Japan and Mexico City. But, the chef says, “hopefully, it will just become a New York restaurant,” a reflection of the city he now calls home. Ilis opens on Oct. 11, ilisnyc.com.
